verses.text: Then the LORD said to me: “Though Moses and Samuel stood before Me, My heart would not be favorable to this people. Send them away from My presence, and let them go.
verses.comment: Moses and Samuel are noted intercessors (cf. Exodus 32:11-14, 1 Samuel 7:9-13), but here even their prayers would not avert judgment. The passage shows the seriousness of stubbornness against God.

verses.text: And if they ask you, ‘Where should we go?’ then tell them: ‘Thus says the LORD: ‘Those marked for death, to death; those marked for the sword, to the sword; those marked for famine, to famine; and those marked for captivity, to captivity.’”
verses.comment: This verse reveals the inevitability of judgment for persistent rebellion. It echoes themes from Ezekiel and elsewhere in Jeremiah about God's sovereignty over the destinies of men.

verses.text: And I will appoint over them four kinds of destroyers, declares the LORD: the sword to kill, the dogs to drag away, the birds of the air and the beasts of the earth to devour and destroy.
verses.comment: The fourfold judgment (sword, dogs, birds, beasts) parallels the punitive measures found in Ezekiel 14:21. Such descriptions invoke both literal and spiritual lessons about God’s justice.

verses.text: And I will make them a horror to all the kingdoms of the earth because of Manasseh the son of Hezekiah, king of Judah, for what he did in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Manasseh’s extreme wickedness is cited as the root cause (see 2 Kings 21:1-16), demonstrating how leadership choices can affect generations following.

verses.text: For who will have pity on you, O Jerusalem, or who will grieve for you? Who will turn aside to ask about your welfare?
verses.comment: This rhetorical lament highlights the isolation resulting from persistent sin—a theological theme later fulfilled in Christ bearing separation for sinful humanity (cf. Lamentations 1:12).

verses.text: You have abandoned Me, declares the LORD, you keep going backward. So I will reach out My hand against you and destroy you—I am weary of relenting.
verses.comment: God’s patience is not limitless; here, the repeated refusals to repent bring divine chastisement. The theme of God’s weariness at continual sin extends through the prophets (cf. Hosea 11:7).

verses.text: I have winnowed them with a winnowing fork at the gates of the land; I have bereaved them, I have destroyed My people; they did not turn from their ways.
verses.comment: The winnowing imagery often relates to divine separation of righteous from wicked (cf. Matthew 3:12). Spiritual application: God purifies His people, sometimes through suffering.

verses.text: I have made their widows more numerous than the sand of the seas; I brought upon them a destroyer at midday against the mothers of young men; suddenly I cast down anguish and terror upon them.
verses.comment: Judgment results in catastrophic loss—even mothers and young men suffer. Compare Jeremiah 6:4 for similar language about sudden attack and devastation.

verses.text: She who bore seven has languished; she has breathed her last. Her sun has set while it is yet day; she is shamed and confounded. The rest of them I will give to the sword before their enemies, declares the LORD.”
verses.comment: The 'mother of seven' symbolizes completeness and fullness, yet even her strength fails under judgment. Daylight turning to night is a motif for sudden disaster.

verses.text: Woe is me, my mother, that you bore me, a man of strife and contention to the whole land! I have not lent, nor have people lent to me, yet all curse me.
verses.comment: Jeremiah laments his role as a prophet, echoing Job’s despair. Prophets often suffer for their faithfulness to God—paralleling Christ’s reception by many during His ministry.

verses.text: The LORD said, “Surely I will deliver you for a good purpose; surely I will cause the enemy to plead for you in the time of disaster and in the time of distress.”
verses.comment: God promises eventual deliverance for His servant—a type that foreshadows both the suffering of the prophets and the greater deliverance found in Christ.

verses.text: Can one break iron, iron from the north, and bronze?
verses.comment: Iron from the north symbolizes invincible strength—Babylon’s might. It recalls God’s promise to make Jeremiah himself an 'iron pillar' (Jeremiah 1:18), showing God’s protection of His chosen.

verses.text: Your wealth and your treasures I will give as plunder, without price, because of all your sins throughout your territory.
verses.comment: Judgment is measured by loss of possessions—a direct consequence of persistent neglect of the covenant.

verses.text: I will make you serve your enemies in a land you do not know, for My anger is a fire that will burn against you.
verses.comment: Exile is foretold as divine retribution, reminiscent of Deuteronomy 28:36. The 'fire of anger' motif points poetically to both God's justice and purifying action (cf. 1 Peter 1:7).

verses.text: O LORD, You know; remember me and care for me, and avenge me against those who persecute me. In Your patience, do not take me away; know that for Your sake I bear reproach.
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s plea for God’s faithfulness under persecution anticipates the suffering servant motif—paralleled in Christ’s endurance of reproach (cf. Psalm 69:7, John 15:25).

verses.text: Your words were found, and I ate them, and Your words became to me a joy and the delight of my heart, for I am called by Your name, O LORD God of armies.
verses.comment: The 'eating' of God’s word is both literal (internalizing) and spiritual (nourishing the soul), echoing themes later picked up in Eucharistic symbolism and prophetic imagery (cf. Revelation 10:9).

verses.text: I did not sit in the company of revelers, nor did I rejoice with them; I sat alone because Your hand was upon me, for You filled me with indignation.
verses.comment: Jeremiah's separation from sinful companions illustrates the call to holiness—see also Psalm 1:1. His isolation mirrors the distinct role of the prophet and, spiritually, the unique call to be set apart.

verses.text: Why is my pain unending and my wound incurable, refusing to be healed? Will You be to me like a deceptive stream, like waters that fail?
verses.comment: Jeremiah expresses doubt and anguish, a human reaction to suffering. Prophets, and later apostles, endure similar periods of apparent abandonment, yet God’s faithfulness will be revealed.

verses.text: Therefore, thus says the LORD: “If you return, I will restore you, and you shall stand before Me; if you separate the precious from the worthless, you shall be as My mouth. Let them return to you, but you shall not return to them.
verses.comment: Restoration is always possible through repentance. The metaphor of being God’s mouth ties to prophetic authority—compare with the commissioning of the apostles.

verses.text: And I will make you to this people a wall of bronze; they may fight against you, but they will not overcome you, for I am with you to save you and deliver you, declares the LORD.
verses.comment: The imagery of a 'wall of bronze' promises supernatural strength and protection—a security later applied spiritually to the community of faith built on God’s promise.

verses.text: I will deliver you from the hand of the wicked, and redeem you from the grasp of the ruthless.
verses.comment: The assurance of deliverance echoes Messianic themes of redemption, ultimately fulfilled spiritually and literally through Christ. Trust in God’s redeeming power is core to the continuity of divine faithfulness.
